sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying wire
message_1: A physics student needs to calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 4 cm from a wire carrying a current of 3 A. The wire has a length of 10 cm and is placed in a vacuum. Calculate the magnetic field strength and direction at the given distance from the wire.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field strength at a distance of 4 cm from a wire carrying a current of 3 A, we can use the Biot-Savart law. The Biot-Savart law states that the magnetic field (dB) produced by a small segment of a current-carrying wire (with current I) is given by:

dB = (μ₀ / 4π) * (Idl x r) / r³

where μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A), dl is the small segment of the wire, r is the vector from the wire segment to the point where we want to calculate the magnetic field, and x denotes the cross product.

Since the wire is straight and has a length of 10 cm, we can simplify the Biot-Savart law by integrating along the length of the wire:

B = (μ₀I / 2πR) * ∫(dl / L)

where R is the distance from the wire (4 cm) and L is the length of the wire (10 cm). The integral of dl / L from 0 to L is 1, so we can simplify the equation to:

B = (μ₀I / 2πR)

Now, we can plug in the values:

B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ T·m/A * 3 A) / (2π * 0.04 m)

B ≈ 1.5 × 10⁻⁵ T

The magnetic field strength at a distance of 4 cm from the wire is approximately 1.5 × 10⁻⁵ T.

To find the direction of the magnetic field, we can use the right-hand rule. If you point your right thumb in the direction of the current (along the wire), your fingers will curl around the wire in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field will form concentric circles around the wire, with the direction depending on the orientation of the wire and the direction of the current.
